docs.lead_paragraph: Yahoo to Pay $235 Million For Web Search Technology Moving to re-establish itself as a pre-eminent place to search the Internet, Yahoo plans to buy Inktomi, a maker of Web search technology, for $235 million in cash. The acquisition provides somewhat of a soft landing for Inktomi, whose shares hit $231 in March 2000 -- giving it a value of about $25 billion -- but whose expansion plans largely collapsed. Market Place. [Page C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Thad Mayfield, 47, was not happy with the remarks that led to Trent Lott's demise as Senate Republican leader. But as a native of Greenwood, Miss. -- just 20 miles from Mr. Lott's birthplace -- he says he understands where Mr. Lott was coming from. He also says he believes he understands why the Republicans forced him from his leadership post. ''It certainly goes against what the president wants to project as the Republican image,'' said Mr. Mayfield, a black management consultant who now lives in Lithonia, Ga. ''Like at the Republican convention, when African-Americans giving the speeches far outnumbered the black delegates. It's image control.''

headline.main: Among Blacks, Mixed Feelings On Fall of Lott

docs.abstract: Black Americans' responses to Sen Trent Lott's removal as majority leader range widely, from newfound approval of Pres Bush to renewed hostility toward him and all Republicans; some credit Bush with engineering Lott's resignation as Senate Republican leader, and many express measure of affection for Bush; others say White House's handling of situation smacks of disloyalty and pandering; say Bush's forceful denunciation and undercutting of Lott seemed directed more at white swing voters than at blacks; say proof of Bush's sincerity will rest on whether he now begins national conversation about race in earnest or seeks merely to put whole subject to rest; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many a book is marketed as a recipe for success or a formula for inspirational change. But, it appears, some recipes for success and wellsprings of life-altering change are found in unlikely literary sources. These days, Steve Kavalgian is the president of Mill River Media in Old Lyme, Conn. He's a publisher's representative, selling advertising space in journals of medicine and professional societies. Life, he says, is terrific.

headline.main: When the Going Gets Tough, Learn From a Book

docs.abstract: Lawrence Van Gelder On the Job column cites six examples of persons greatly helped by books when they encountered difficulties in their work; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If anyone finds coal in his stocking this Christmas, John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric, might be a good candidate. So says Jobs With Justice, a worker advocacy group, that named G.E. ''National Grinch of the Year 2002'' because of Mr. Welch's lavish retirement package. Each year Jobs With Justice makes the award to draw attention to those in powerful positions who, in its view, have done the most to hurt working families. In an Internet poll, G.E. won, with 37 percent of 1,700 votes cast. The company was cited for proposing increases in payments that G.E. workers and retirees must pay for their health plan, while giving Mr. Welch a multimillion-dollar retirement package that included payments for his apartment, V.I.P. tickets at Yankee Stadium, and even his laundry. ''While G.E. picks the pockets of working families and retirees, it is lavishing perks on current and retired executives,'' the group. ''The most notorious is former C.E.O. Jack Welch.''

headline.main: Private Sector; It's Big, Starts with G, Has Lots of Green

docs.abstract: Worker advocacy group Jobs With Justice names General Electric 'National Grinch of the Year 2000' for giving lavish retirement package to former chief executive John F Welch Jr while proposing workers pay more for their health plans (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Carlos Guevara sat hunched over a sewing machine in a Brooklyn garment factory, 10 hours a day, six days a week. Every 15 to 30 seconds, he would push a white cotton neck lining off to the side of his table. Six cents.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Tough Times Translate Into Layoffs, Fewer Hours and Deprivation

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was a Sunday and, as usual, Guy Magnan was in church. That day, someone from Habitat for Humanity - New York City happened to come by to talk about its program of building houses for people who cannot afford to buy them. The group passed out application forms, and Mr. Magnan, who is 31 and works in sales for Sears, took one. He was living in a $700-a-month one-bedroom apartment in Queens with his grandmother, his cousin and his cousin's daughter. For 10 years, he had slept on a pullout sofa in the living room, without any privacy. He had looked into buying a house and had been approved for a mortgage, but the costs worried him.

headline.main: Habitats/South Jamaica, Queens; A Family Helps to Build A House of Their Own

docs.lead_paragraph: EDGY investors have pushed down prices of blue-chip companies sharply this year despite strong company fundamentals, says Robert W. Smith,manager of the $3.9 billion T. Rowe Price Growth Stock fund. ''Valuations are being cut in half because people have lost faith in the stock market and don't know who to trust,'' Mr. Smith said from his office in downtown Baltimore. ''Minor issues have become major problems,'' he added, and price-to-earnings multiples have taken big hits.

headline.main: INVESTING WITH/Robert W. Smith; T. Rowe Price Growth Stock Fund
